Agents asked for the whereabouts of a person whose name her son did not recognize and briefly detained him when he could not provide information, Mejia said. One of the agents appeared to realize they had the wrong person and let her son go, she said.
Mejia and her son are U.S. citizens. Agents said they were looking for a young man from El Salvador.
“The family is Mexican American,” said Mejia’s attorney, Christian Contreras. “It feels as if they were exploited, abused and taken advantage of because of the color of their skin.”
The interaction has left lasting scars on her son, who now suffers from nightmares and sometimes “breaks down” in tears when she’s driving, Mejia said.
“People with the slightest shade of brown in their skin in L.A. fear that they may be the target of immigration officials,” Contreras said. “It’s across the board now.”

title: Dick Durbin calls for Senate hearing on Trump's threats to send troops to cities like Chicago
summary: The Trump administration has targeted Democratic-run cities, with the president suggesting Wednesday that New Orleans could be on his list.
story: The top Democrat on the Senate Judiciary Committee is calling on the panel’s Republican chairman to hold a hearing on President Donald Trump’s threats to deploy military forces to Chicago and other cities.

“Domestic deployment of the military into American communities raises serious issues within the jurisdiction of the Judiciary Committee that warrant an immediate hearing,” Sen. Dick Durbin, D-Ill., wrote in a letter Wednesday to Senate Judiciary Committee Chairman Chuck Grassley, R-Iowa.

“Of particular relevance for this Committee is that the men and women serving in our Armed Forces are trained primarily for warfighting, not community policing and safeguarding civil liberties. Unlawfully and unnecessarily deploying troops to engage in law enforcement in local communities, instead of the duties they are trained for, undermines military readiness and endangers American communities,” he added.
Durbin contended that police power to ensure residents’ safety is a duty that rests with state and local officials, not the federal government.

“The recent threats by the President to send troops or federal officers into American cities to address local crime or other issues within state control over the objection of state officials imperil this foundational principle and the rights of all states,” Durbin wrote.

Reached for comment, Grassley's communications director, Clare Slattery, said in an email that "the Senate Judiciary Committee is in the planning stages for a hearing on the Trump administration’s effective strategies for reducing crime and protecting the American people."
Details on the timing of such a hearing were not immediately available.

Trump has indicated that he will send federal forces into cities across the country, saying “We’re going in” when asked at the White House on Tuesday whether he’d be sending National Guard troops to Chicago. Trump suggested Wednesday that he could send federal troops to New Orleans.
The comments were the latest in the Trump administration’s efforts to send troops to cities run by Democrats.
Last month, the president ramped up law enforcement in the nation’s capital as part of what he has described as an effort to crack down on crime and homelessness.

A federal judge ruled Tuesday that Trump had violated a federal law that prohibits using soldiers for civilian law enforcement activities when he sent the National Guard and Marines to Los Angeles in June to respond to protests against the administration’s immigration enforcement tactics.

title: 'Venezuela has been a very bad actor,' Trump says, threatening escalation
summary: The Trump administration is warning would-be drug traffickers that they will meet the same fate as those killed in a boat the U.S blew up Tuesday in the southern Caribbean, a dramatic escalation in the drug war and the White House's bitter feud with Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro.“Venezuela has been a very bad actor,” President Donald Trump said Wednesday in the Oval Office
story: The Trump administration is warning would-be drug traffickers that they will meet the same fate as those killed in a boat the U.S blew up Tuesday in the southern Caribbean, a dramatic escalation in the drug war and the White House's bitter feud with Venezuelan leader Nicolás Maduro.
“Venezuela has been a very bad actor,” President Donald Trump said Wednesday in the Oval Office.

The U.S.’s offensive posture in the region is raising questions about its ultimate goal — and how U.S. intelligence agencies were so certain that the boat contained drugs and members of the notorious Venezuelan gang Tren de Aragua.
“We have tapes of them speaking,” Trump said. “It was massive amounts of drugs coming into our country to kill a lot of people.”

Though the president’s specific intentions regarding Maduro are unclear, the U.S. seems to have two objectives: stemming the flow of illegal drugs from Venezuela and placing debilitating pressure on the Venezuelan leader.

The goal is to force Maduro to make rash decisions that could ultimately lead to his ouster — without American boots on the ground — according to a source familiar with the Trump administration’s thinking.

A second source familiar said that last week the administration privately signaled plans to intensify pressure on Venezuela, saying the situation was about to quickly escalate and that Maduro “had a lot to worry about.”
“There’s definitely going to be more to come” with regard to hitting drug cartel operations, the source said.

In 2019, during Trump’s first term, his administration recognized Venezuelan opposition leader Juan Guaidó as interim president while Maduro faced mass protests after years of hyperinflation and a string of blackouts. Despite the U.S. backing of Guaidó, Maduro held onto power.
Last month, some members of the Venezuelan opposition movement visited the State Department for meetings with top officials, according to two people familiar with the talks.
Rubio's role
Marco Rubio has long been a hardliner on Venezuela, as a senator, as a presidential candidate, and now as secretary of state as well as national security advisor.

The source familiar with the administration’s thinking believes regime change in Venezuela has been Rubio’s goal. The administration is preparing for this by not recognizing Maduro as a legitimate president, accusing him of rigging elections and  alleging he’s a narco-terrorist, the head of the Cartel de Los Soles. Several weeks ago, the U.S. doubled its reward for information leading to Maduro’s arrest to $50 million.

The source familiar with the administration’s thinking said the U.S. hopes that ramping up pressure on Maduro may prompt finger-pointing inside Venezuela and lead cartel bosses inside and outside the country to blame Maduro and force him out. The source speculated that Russia — not wanting to get involved in a domestic power struggle — would pull its financial, diplomatic and military support from Venezuela, long considered its ally.
Tuesday’s military strike on the alleged drug smuggling boat, which Trump said killed 11 people and did not hurt U.S. forces, came as a surprise to many members of Congress.

Democrats, even those in leadership positions on relevant oversight committees, have not been provided with any information about the strike, according to multiple congressional officials with direct knowledge of the situation. It’s not clear what information, if any, Republicans were given before or after the strike.
Rubio defended the strike on Wednesday while visiting Mexico, arguing that the typical interdiction procedures that the U.S. Coast Guard conducts to arrest drug smugglers didn’t work in these cases.
“These drug cartels, what they do is they know they’re going to lose 2% of their cargo,” Rubio said. “They bake it into their economics. What will stop them is when you blow them up.”
Additional U.S. military forces

Last month, the U.S. began sending more military resources, including three guided-missile destroyers, to the southern Caribbean. Stephen Donehoo, a former military intelligence officer specializing in Latin America, told NBC News the deployment was enormous.

“I haven’t seen this much U.S. naval military force in the Caribbean under the command of the Southern Command in decades,” Donehoo said. “All these ships have intelligence systems, and they are also armed to carry out this type of attack if necessary.”

In the last few weeks, Maduro has claimed the U.S. military presence in the Caribbean is aimed at overthrowing his government. He has deployed troops along the border while calling on thousands of civilians to join armed militias to defend the nation.
A senior White House official downplayed any possibility of the U.S. invading Venezuela, but said, “You can expect to see the president use any means necessary to tackle drug cartels.”
On Fox News Wednesday morning, Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth was asked about whether the administration’s goal was regime change in Venezuela. Notably, he did not rule it out.
“That’s a presidential decision,” Hegseth said.
The second source familiar with the administration’s thinking dismissed any threat posed by Venezuela’s troops and expressed skepticism that the country’s armed forces would remain loyal to Maduro.
“It’s a house of cards,” the source added, speculating that Maduro would see the writing on the wall and flee the country, perhaps to Cuba.
Maduro pushback
For its part, the Maduro government has escalated its criticism of the White House, even claiming the video of Tuesday’s attack on the alleged drug trafficking boat was created using AI.
“I can tell you that was definitely not artificial intelligence,” Hegseth said in the Fox interview. “I watched it live.”
In comments broadcast on Venezuelan state television Tuesday night, Maduro alluded to what he considered Rubio’s significant power within the Trump administration regarding Venezuela policy.

“The youth of the United States do not believe the lies of the big shot in the White House, Marco Rubio," Maduro said. "Because who runs the White House is Marco Rubio — the mafia of Miami — who wants to fill Donald Trump’s hands with blood.”
More actions expected
The Trump administration’s strike against the cartel boat may only be the beginning of its actions in the region.

In February, the State Department designated eight drug cartels and criminal organizations as foreign terrorist organizations and specially designated global terrorists. That gave the White House new legal authorities to take military action against such groups throughout the Western Hemisphere.
Asked about the cartels in an interview last month, Rubio said it was time they were treated “as armed terrorist organizations, not simply drug -dealing organizations.”

The Secretary of State said the new designations would allow the Trump administration to target the cartel’s operations using other elements of American power, including U.S. intelligence agencies and the Department of Defense.

“It is a criminal enterprise — all the way to the various cartels that operate in Mexico, and in between,” Rubio said. “So, what it changes is it gives us legal authorities to target them in ways you can’t do if they’re just a bunch of criminals. It’s no longer a law enforcement issue. It becomes a national security issue.”

title: Here's why you shouldn't take your smartphone into the bathroom
summary: Excessive scrolling on smartphones while on the toilet can lead to itchy, painful hemorrhoids, finds a new study.
story: Of all the crappy ways smartphones have affected our health, this one is a real kick in the pants.
A first-of-its-kind study links excessive scrolling on the phone while sitting on the toilet with hemorrhoids.
(Insert poo emojis.)
But, seriously. Sitting on an open bowl offers no support for the pelvic floor. That puts pressure on veins in the rectum, making them swollen and inflamed.

“The longer you sit on the toilet, the worse it is for you,” said Dr. Trisha Pasricha, director of the Beth Israel Deaconess Medical Center’s Institute for Gut-Brain Research Institute in Boston. Pasricha is also an author of the study, which was published Wednesday in PLOS One.

And smartphones are designed to keep people fixated for as long as possible. “They’re completely consuming to us in ways that wasn’t happening to the casual bathroom reader in the 80s,” Pasricha said. “They could much more easily put the newspaper down and get up and leave.”
Pasricha and colleagues surveyed 125 adults just before they were about to have a routine colonoscopy to screen for colorectal cancer.
Eighty-three (66%) of the participants admitted to using their phones in the bathroom — mostly to catch up on news of the day and scroll through social media.

Gastroenterologists performing the colonoscopies looked for evidence of inflamed veins, or hemorrhoids. People who said they took their phone into the bathroom were 46% more likely to have hemorrhoids compared to the others.
The risk remained even when researchers accounted for other factors associated with hemorrhoids, including dietary fiber, exercise and constipation or straining while using the toilet.

Hemorrhoids aren’t necessarily dangerous, but they can be bothersome, itchy and even painful. They also bleed sometimes, understandably causing concern and leading to nearly 4 million doctor’s office and emergency department visits a year.

Over time, “pelvic floor dysfunction can also lead to incontinence, worsen constipation and be associated with rectal pain,” said Dr. Reezwana Chowdhury, an inflammatory bowel disorder specialist at the Johns Hopkins University School of Medicine. Chowdhury was not involved with the new research.
What’s more, microscopic particles from urine and feces are sent flying through the air when a toilet is flushed. Taking a phone into the bathroom, Chowdhury said, “is kind of gross.”
Younger patients
In the new study, smartphone users in the bathroom tended to be younger, meaning adults in their 40s and 50s, versus people over age 60.
Dr. Robert Cima, a colorectal surgeon at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minnesota, said he’s noticed an uptick in recent years of people coming in with hemorrhoids.

“I am seeing younger, earlier- and middle-aged people having more hemorrhoidal complaints, but I can’t tie it to smartphones,” said Cima, who was not involved with the new study. “Maybe it’s because they’re using smartphones or they have better access to care or they’re not eating appropriately.”
The 5-minute rule
The experts agreed that business on the toilet should take no longer than 5 minutes.
More than 37% of study participants who used a smartphone in the bathroom stayed for longer than that, compared to 7% of people who kept their phones out of the bathroom.
Pasricha and other experts do not advocate for taking a phone into the bathroom. If you absolutely must, set a timer.
“If the magic is not happening within five minutes, it’s not going to happen,” Pasricha said. “Take a breather and try again later.”

title: 'SNL' and Lonely Island Star Jorma Taccone Shatters Pelvis After Falling From 20-Foot Ladder
summary: Jorma Taccone, a former "Saturday Night Live" writer who's also in the comedy trio The Lonely Island, is recovering from a shattered pelvis and other injuries after falling 20 feet from a ladder.
story: Jorma Taccone, a former “Saturday Night Live” writer who’s also  in the comedy trio The Lonely Island, is recovering from a shattered pelvis and other injuries after falling 20 feet from a ladder while painting a birthday mural for his daughter.
Taccone, 48, shared his terrifying health update when he phoned into “The Lonely Island & Seth Meyers Podcast” from his hospital bed during the show’s Sept. 2 episode.
Taccone, who described himself as a “very active guy,” said he was painting the mural on a barn at his family’s farmhouse in Connecticut ahead of his daughter’s fifth birthday.
“I’m using this ladder that my neighbor let me borrow, and he was like, ‘Hey, this ladder is bad, like, you shouldn’t use this ladder. This doesn’t have a footing thing.’ I was like, ‘It’ll be good.”
Taccone said he was “almost done” with the mural when he felt the “very rickety ladder” give way beneath him.

“In this moment, my life flashes before my eyes. I’m like, ‘Oh no, I’ve got to get off this ladder.’ I literally had enough time as I’m falling to be like, I’m going to die. I drop. I look over. I see the yard, I’m like, this is going to hurt a lot,” he recalled.

“And I fall straight on my butt, taking all of the impact on my butt,” he continued. “Then I do a lot of screaming and cursing. Keep in mind, it’s my daughter’s fifth birthday party, so it wasn’t the coolest way to start the day. I’m like, ‘Call an ambulance!’”
At the hospital, Taccone learned that he’d shattered his pelvis in the “life-changing” accident, which also caused his sacrum to become “detached” from his spine.
“By the way, all of this sounds way worse than it is,” he said, causing his co-hosts — fellow “SNL” alums Seth Meyers, Andy Samberg and Akiva Schaffer — to erupt in laughter.
“I’m in a hospital bed right now,” Taccone added. “This is two days post-surgery.”
Taccone went on to say that a disc in his back was also “bad” after the accident, so doctors opted to “chuck that out.”
Taccone now plans to do physical therapy in an “acute rehab” to help his body heal. His doctors predict he will be able to walk again in three to six months.
“I do get a lot of credit here, which is nice,” Taccone joked of his hospital stay. “Everyone who talks to me is like, ‘Oh wow, that’s real painful!’”
“I know I’m laughing about it now,” he added, “but it is probably like the most rugged thing I will ever experience.”

title: Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi Give Steamy Preview of 'Wuthering Heights' in 1st Look
summary: The first trailer for the latest film adaptation of Emily Brontë’s 1847 classic novel “Wuthering Heights” gives a preview into a steamy romance between Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi's characters.
story: This is not the “Wuthering Heights” from grade school English class.

The first trailer for the latest film adaptation of Emily Brontë’s 1847 classic novel “Wuthering Heights” gives a preview into a steamy romance between Catherine Earnshaw and Heathcliff, played by Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi.
Resembling the style of director Emerald Fennell’s 2023 provocative and comedic thriller “Saltburn,” the “Wuthering Heights” trailer features erotic shots of dough, egg yolks and a fish mouth.
The flashes of erogenous scenes are interwoven among snippets of Robbie and Elordi in a seemingly passionate yet tumultuous relationship.
The words “Drive Me Mad” appear over the compilation of simultaneously romantic, heartbreaking and sexually suggestive clips.
The teaser ends in a shadowy scene, with Elordi’s Heathcliff seemingly holding the hands of Robbie’s Catherine Earnshaw as he asks, “Do you want me to stop?”
She can be heard letting out a breathy, “No.”
The film is set to hit theaters on Feb. 13, 2026, the day before Valentine’s Day.
In the comments on YouTube, users were fanning off from all the sensual moments, deeming the movie, “Fifty Shades of Grey: 1800s Version,” in reference to the famously arousing franchise.
Based on the first look, one already called the film a “promising masterpiece.” Meanwhile, others drew similarities to Fennell’s last film.
“Wow. Saltburn 2 looks great!” one user joked.
Another commented, “It feels like Emerald is taking Saltburn to the next level with this one.”
The trailer noted the film is set to feature original songs by singer Charli XCX, which delighted her fans.
One user commented, “A charli xcx song on this?? SEATED.”
Others, however, were torn on the modern take on Brontë’s novel, with one user calling it an “abomination” of the original work.

“I’ve never felt more contradicted about a film being right up my alley but being an abomination to the sentiment of the source material, which happens to be one of my favorite books,” the comment read.

Another was less shocked by the filmmaker’s interpretation, writing, “Always knew Emerald Fennell’s version would be a reimagined Wuthering Heights, not a straight adaptation of the Bronte novel. And with songs by (Charli) XCX. Film will be as divisive as Saltburn — but that’s why I love movies.”

Primarily set in late 1700s England, Brontë’s novel tells the love story of Catherine Earnshaw and the orphan her father adopted, Heathcliff. Despite their intense connection, Catherine marries another man for wealth, severing her bond with Heathcliff. He becomes haunted by his love for Catherine while their lives take dramatically different turns.

title: Why 'The Office' Star Oscar Nuñez Agreed to Be in 'The Paper'
summary: Dunder Mifflin accountant Oscar Martinez is returning to television, and the actor who plays him, Oscar Nuñez, couldn't be happier
story: Dunder Mifflin accountant Oscar Martinez is returning to television, and the actor who plays him, Oscar Nuñez, couldn't be happier.

Nuñez, 66, revives his character Oscar for Peacock’s new original series “The Paper,” a spinoff of “The Office” premiering Sept. 4. The mockumentary-style sitcom follows along as the same fictional documentary crew that lingered around Dunder Mifflin for all those years now sets up to film in the newsroom of a historic Midwestern newspaper that’s seen better days.

Playing Oscar again was “like riding a bicycle,” Nuñez told Entertainment Weekly. In the new series, Oscar has moved from Scranton, Pennsylvania, to Toledo, Ohio, where he works as the head accountant for the paper.
“(Oscar's) probably glad to get out of Scranton,” Nuñez added. “And I hope he’s getting more money.”

In “The Paper,” Oscar once again works for an eccentric boss. This time, it’s newspaper managing editor Esmeralda Grand (Sabrina Impacciatore), who butts heads with the paper’s new editor-in-chief Ned Sampson (Domhnall Gleeson).
Esmeralda is so scheming, she might even scare off Oscar's old boss Michael Scott (Steve Carell).
“He’d probably be a little bit intimidated,” Nuñez told EW of the two characters. “He’d probably try to hit on her first and then probably take a step back. They’re a little bit similar."
As for why Oscar is the only “The Office” character to wind up on “The Paper,” Greg Daniels, the creator of “The Office” who co-created the “The Paper,” says it’s simple.
When “The Office” ended, Oscar’s story was the only one that “didn’t have as much arc to it,” Daniels told People.

“So I didn’t feel bad about involving him because most of the other characters, I feel like they had a really good ending at the finale and I didn’t want to open that up and risk messing up the original show,” he explained.

Daniels described the Oscar character as “a dignified person pretty much throughout,” who “got in a little bit of a messy triangle” with Angela Martin in Season 9 but “learned his lesson over the course of the thing.”
“I think he had that ability to have more juice and more stories about him that you were curious about without harming things,” said Daniels.

title: 'The Kelly Clarkson Show' Reveals Season 7 Premiere Date, Celebrity Guests
summary: “The Kelly Clarkson Show” is just weeks away from returning for its seventh season.
story: “The Kelly Clarkson Show” is just weeks away from returning for its seventh season.
The NBC talk show announced in a press release that it will resume filming for Season 7 next week starting Monday, Sept. 8, with new episodes set to begin airing Monday, Sept. 29.
The press release also revealed the group of celebrity guests who will appear in upcoming episodes, including Emily Blunt, Marion Cotillard and Colin Farrell.

Some more famous faces slated to make their way to Clarkson’s New York City set are Scarlett Johansson, Dwayne Johnson, Matthew McConaughey, Lionel Richie, Julia Roberts, Shonda Rhimes, Margot Robbie, Sylvester Stallone, Channing Tatum and Reese Witherspoon.

Viewers should expect an emotional return for the daytime talk show, as the press release revealed “Season 7 premiere week will spotlight the heroes who rescued campers from the devastating flood in Texas in July.”
But, fans should also anticipate a season filled with more joyful, music-filled moments that the show has become known for.

“This season fans can look forward to more entertaining panel interviews, exclusive celebrity moments, surprise musical performances and the return of the wildly popular ‘Kellyoke’ segment, where Clarkson highlights extraordinary emerging and established artists and delivers show-stopping covers of hits spanning every genre, backed by her band, Y’All,” the press release said.

Season 7 of “The Kelly Clarkson Show” will arrive following the recent death of host Kelly Clarkson’s ex-husband, Brandon Blackstock, on Aug. 7. After Season 6 of her show wrapped on June 25, Clarkson spent part of the summer performing her “Studio Sessions” shows in Las Vegas. But on Aug. 6, she shared on social media that she needed to postpone her remaining concerts due to Blackstock’s illness.
The next day, Blackstock’s family released a statement sharing that the talent manager had died at the age of 48 following a three-year battle with cancer.

“It is with great sadness that we share the news that Brandon Blackstock has passed away,” his family said in the statement. “Brandon bravely battled cancer for more than three years. He passed away peacefully and was surrounded by family. We thank you for your thoughts and prayers and ask everyone to respect the family’s privacy during this very difficult time.”
Services for Blackstock, the father of Clarkson’s two children, were held Aug. 17, according to the Axelson Funeral & Cremation Services website.

title: Novak Djokovic Busts Out ‘KPop Demon Hunters’ Dance After US Open Win for Daughter’s Birthday
summary: Novak Djokovic performed a dance from "KPop Demon Hunters" after he won his quarterfinal match at the U.S. Open, saying he did it for his daughter.
story: Novak Djokovic showed off all the right moves in his latest win at the U.S. Open.
The legendary tennis player put on an impromptu dance performance inspired by the smash Netflix movie “KPop Demon Hunters” after he defeated Taylor Fritz to move into the semifinals on Sept 2.
“It’s my daughter’s birthday, so this is a big present for her,” he said after the match, referring to his daughter, Tara.
“Actually, the dance, in the end, she’s going to rate me tomorrow," he added.

Djokovic's moves were part of the choreography for “Soda Pop,” a song by one of the movie's fictional bands, the Saja Boys. "KPop Demon Hunters," as the title suggests, follows a girl band who moonlights as demon slayers. The movie, which has even captivated fathers who’ve seen it, features several catchy songs, four of which currently sit in the top 10 of the Billboard Hot 100.

“Obviously, it’s a big thing globally for teenagers and for kids, but I didn’t know about it before my daughter told me a few months ago about it,” Djokovic said after the match. “So we’re at home doing different choreographies, and this is one of them, so hopefully I’ll make her smile when she wakes up tomorrow morning.”
He later posted a photo of himself mid-dance move to X, captioning it, "For Tara. Soda popping into semifinal."

The seventh-seeded Djokovic, 38, will need to show off some more fancy footwork when he plays No. 2 seed Carlos Alcaraz with a berth in the finals of the U.S. Open on the line. That semifinal match will take place Sept. 5.

title: From Julia Roberts to Timothée Chalamet: 25 'Law & Order' Guest Stars You May Have Forgotten
summary: In honor of 25 seasons of "Law & Order" on NBC, take a look back at 25 of the most famous guest stars, like Stephen A. Smith, Cynthia Nixon and Colman Domingo.
story: "Law & Order" has provided big breaks and resume fodder to hundreds, if not thousands, of actors over the years.
The NBC series, which will celebrate its 25th season Sep. 25, originally premiered in 1990 and still runs today, though there was that hiatus between 2010-2022.

It can feel like nearly every resident of New York City has had some spot as an extra or guest star. (Heck, even the writer of this very article appeared in the background of a courtroom scene in the Season 10 episode called "Gunshow.")
It's no surprise that among those scores of guest stars, several turned out to be at the start of brilliant careers, while others were stars in their own rights before stepping onto the set.
Ahead of the landmark launch of the new season, look back at some of the stars who popped up in arresting appearances over the years.
Cynthia Nixon

“Law & Order” was virtually brand new when future Emmy-winner Nixon, who would go on to appear on screen with “L&O” regular cast member Chris Noth in “Sex and the City,” appeared as a ballerina named Laura Di Biasi who exacted vigilante justice on the New York City subway in 1990.

In 2007, Nixon guest-starred on “Law & Order: Special Victims Unit,” which earned her an Emmy for outstanding guest actress in a drama series. A few years later, she also appeared on an episode of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.”
Philip Seymour Hoffman

Hoffman, who would go on to win an Oscar in 2006, showed up in “L&O’s” first season in his first professional credited role as Steven Hanauer, who faced trial after a group sexual assault on a reporter.
Courtney B. Vance

In time, two-time Emmy winner Vance (“Lovecraft Country,” “American Crime Story”) would go on to play Assistant District Attorney Ron Carver for five seasons on “Law & Order: Criminal Intent,” but he first guested on two different episodes of the mothership series.

His first appearance in 1990 was uncredited. He played an assistant to the mayor in an episode about a call girl organization run by a socialite. His 1995 role as Benjamin “Bud” Greer was meatier, though. When Bud’s mentor turned up dead, he used a defense of “Black rage” in court.
Allison Janney

In the world of “L&O” fans, someone who appears on the show more than once is referred to as a “repeat offender," and Oscar-winner Janney (“The West Wing,” “The Diplomat”) fits the bill, with two mothership appearances two years apart.
She first appeared in the small role of Nora during a 1992 episode about the beating of a soap-opera actress. In 1994, she returned as Ann Madsen, a terrified witness to a horrific crime.
Claire Danes

Danes, who would go on to win three Emmys for her work in “Temple Grandin” and “Homeland,” played Tracy Brandt — a young model for a shady photographer. At the time of this pre-“My So-Called Life” appearance on the series in 1992, Danes was only 13 and making her TV debut.
Elaine Stritch

Stritch was an Emmy- and Tony-winning powerhouse of the theatrical world (“Company,” “Elaine Stritch at Liberty”) who also charmed on TV (“30 Rock”). She added “L&O” to her extensive resume by playing sassy, canny defense attorney Lanie Stieglitz on two episodes in 1992 and 1997. She’s the only actor to have won an Emmy for the series.
Edie Falco

Unlike most celebrities mentioned here, four-time Emmy winner Falco (“Nurse Jackie,” “The Sopranos”) had a recurring role on the series, playing Legal Aid defense attorney Sally Bell. She appeared in four episodes between 1993-1998.
Bell sparked and clashed beautifully with then-Executive Assistant District Attorney Jack McCoy (Sam Waterston) in the courtroom.
Eventually, Falco went on to star as real-life attorney Leslie Abramson in “Law & Order True Crime: The Menendez Murders.”
Julianna Margulies

Margulies’ long, successful run on TV series like “ER” and “The Good Wife” was still to come when the future three-time Emmy winner appeared as Lt. Ruth Mendoza, who got wrapped up in the death of a fellow naval officer in 1993.
J.K. Simmons

Oscar-winner Simmons has a curious history with the show, going from guest star to crossover guest star to recurring regular. His first appearance was as Jerry Luppin in a 1994 episode about a hit-and-run car accident in which a businessman killed a boy in Harlem.
But in 1996 he made an appearance on “Homicide: Life on the Street” that crossed over with “L&O” as Col. Alexander Rausch.

Finally, he settled nicely into the recurring part of police psychiatrist Emil Skoda for 44 episodes between 1997 and 2010. He also played Skoda on a few episodes of “Law & Order: SVU” and an episode of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.”
Sarah Paulson

Future Emmy winner Paulson (“American Crime Story”) racked up her first known professional on-camera credit as an actor in 1994, playing Maggie Conner — a teenager who’d been sleeping with her stepfather — and whose mother’s manner of death came under suspicion. She later guest-starred in an episode of “SVU” in 2010.
Laura Linney

“Ozark” star and three-time Oscar nominee Linney was moving up in the world of acting with roles in films like “Searching for Bobby Fischer” and “A Simple Twist of Fate” when she made her series TV debut in 1994.

On “L&O,” she portrayed Martha Bowen, a struggling performer who tried to break through in Japan while working under a shady nightclub owner. The owner was killed while visiting the U.S., and Bowen became the main suspect. Bowen was ultimately acquitted   after her lawyer used battered woman syndrome as her defense.
Ellen Pompeo
She’s been a medical heroine since 2005 on “Grey’s Anatomy,” but before that, Pompeo showed a truly dark side to her angelic face in two mothership episodes.

In 1996, she co-starred alongside future “Grey’s” actor Brooke Smith as Jenna Weber, a young woman whose family is brutally murdered. Four years later, she was back as Laura Kendrick, who came under suspicion for the deaths of multiple people, including her sister, after making a deal with prosecutors.
Julia Roberts
Sometimes actors get hired based on who they’re dating, but we’re positive that doesn’t apply to megastar and future Oscar winner Julia Roberts.

She appeared on the series in 1999 as she was dating cast regular Benjamin Bratt. Roberts played against type as a scheming sports stadium investor who poisoned a major sponsor in the deal (with whom she was having an affair).

She did her best to put the moves on Bratt’s Detective Curtis, but he turned her down. She earned a first Emmy nomination in the outstanding guest actress in a drama category that same year for playing the part.
Zoe Saldaña
Saldaña, who won an Oscar for her performance in “Emilia Pérez,” earned her first on-screen credit as Belinca in the second episode of a two-parter called “Refuge.”
In the episode, a young boy witnessed a murder when a driver got into a shootout with the police. Belinca gave the investigating detectives a key lead in solving the case.
Chris Messina

Another repeat offender in the “L&O” universe, future “The Mindy Project” star Messina got his first official pro credit appearing on not one but two episodes in the sixth season, one in 1995 and one in 1996.

He played Tommy Bell, a rich kid murdered in a biker bar in “Rebels,” and a smaller part in “Homesick,” about an infant’s poisoning. Years later, he played Don Cushman in an episode about the shooting of an off-duty police officer.
Kerry Washington

Washington’s big movie (“Django Unchained,” “Ray”) and TV (“Scandal”) career was still to come in 2001, when she appeared in an episode about a murder in a nightclub. She played Allie Lawrence, a singer involved in the shooting of a musician, and few people stepped forward as witnesses.
Bonus: The episode also included a pre-“Luther” Idris Elba, who played a DJ and witness to the shooting.

Washington posted about the episode on Instagram in March, sharing a brief clip from the show and wondering in the caption how it might have gone differently if current “L&O” star, and her former “Scandal” co-star, Tony Goldwyn, had been “grilling” her character instead of Waterston's McCoy.
“I would have been a lot tougher on you than Sam was,” Goldwyn quipped in the comments.
Jennifer Garner
As a graduate student named Jaime who bonded with the married Detective Curtis Bratt after he witnessed a prisoner’s execution, Garner made her lone “L&O” appearance in 1996.
Sebastian Stan

Before becoming Bucky Barnes in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, future Oscar nominee Stan popped up, alongside Ty Burrell, in 2003’s “Sheltered” as Justin Lafferty/Justin Capshaw, a grown man who was kidnapped as a baby.
Colman Domingo

Before becoming an Oscar-nominated actor, Domingo guest-starred in the 14th and 19th seasons of “Law & Order.” He played a defense attorney in his first appearance and a character named Donnie in the 2008 episode about the murder of an author.
Domingo also appeared on “Law & Order: Trial by Jury” in 2006 and two episodes of “Law & Order: Criminal Intent.”
Laverne Cox

Like Domingo, Laverne Cox (“Orange Is the New Black”) made a guest appearance in “Sweetie.” The future Emmy nominee portrayed a prostitute named Minnie. That same year, she also appeared in an episode of “SVU.”
Sarah Hyland
Five years before she began co-starring on “Modern Family,” the then-13-year-old Hyland played Kristine McLean in a 2004 episode about a young woman who drowned after a ferry crash.
She also appeared in a 2005 episode of “Law & Order: Trial by Jury” and two episodes of “Law & Order: SVU.”
Timothée Chalamet

Young Chalamet (“Dune”) was a newcomer to TV in 2009, when he played Eric Foley, the son of two scientists. Eric was murdered by a man who had a crush on Eric’s mother way back in the day. Chalamet was still eight years away from his big, Oscar-nominated breakthrough in “Call Me by Your Name.”
Sasha Alexander
Having already been paired up with former “L&O” regular Angie Harmon on “Rizzoli & Isles,” Alexander got her turn in the mothership’s spotlight in 2023 as Kristin Bartell.
The episode focused on the death of a doctor with a political wife, played by Alexander, who suspected she was the actual target of the murder.
Stephen A. Smith
Radio host, TV personality and sports analyst Smith was already well known when he appeared in Season 24 as a “tough love” sports agent who ended up stabbed.

“It was an incredible experience,” he told Deadline. “I did some acting before I was that dead body. … I actually have a scene where I’m doing some acting, and to have the opportunity to do it on one of my all-time favorite shows is an honor beyond comprehension.”
Katie Lowes

Lowes, best known for her roles on “Scandal” and “The Hunting Wives,” played Victoria Beyer on the series early in 2025 as a daughter who helped her ill father go through with an assisted suicide plot.

title: David Duchovny Is Married! The Actor and Writer Confirms the News on TODAY
summary: On the TODAY show, "The X-Files" star David Duchovny told Savannah Guthrie and Willie Geist he got married in February. He has been linked to Monique Pendleberry.
story: David Duchovny is officially a married man!
While appearing on TODAY with Jenna & Friends on Sept. 3, the actor shared the exciting news.
The 65-year-old didn't offer up many details about his nuptials or his bride, but he did confirm that he recently tied the knot when Savannah Guthrie brought up the topic.
"By the way, you got married this year," she said. "Congratulations!"
"I did, in February. Thank you," he replied.
Duchovny, known for his roles in "The X-Files" and "Californication," didn't mention his wife by name, but he has been linked to his longtime girlfriend, Monique Pendleberry, since 2017, per People.
Fourth hour guest co-host Willie Geist couldn't resist asking the actor, who is publishing his debut book of poetry called “About Time,” if any of his poems are directed toward his wife.

"No, no," he said. "You know, it's funny, I was checking the Amazon sales on the way here this morning, and it said I was No. 1 love poet, which is the funniest thing. That's just such a joke because there's no other love poet out there. So I'm one of one."
Duchovny was previously married to Téa Leoni from 1997-2014 and shares two children with the actor: a 26-year-old daughter named West and a 23-year-old son named Kyd.

Duchovny and Pendleberry have managed to stay mostly out of the spotlight in recent years but have made a few public appearances together. In 2023, they were seen together on the red carpet at the Tribeca Festival.
The couple were also spotted looking cozy at the Los Angeles premiere of "You People" that same year.
In a 2024 essay for The Times, Duchovny opened up about why he loves mornings and some of his thoughts on love.
He explained he likes to get up early because he sees that time of day as his "best thinking and writing hours."
"I love the sunrise but it also means I can get some work done before the sun gets too much. That’s the best time of day for me," he said.
He also shared what his daughter thought of his 2023 movie with Meg Ryan, "What Happens Later."

"My daughter, West, thought it was great to see a romantic comedy film with people my age, but I don’t think of myself as any age, so I hadn’t thought about that. Love can happen at any age, right?" he said.

title: 6 Books to Read This September, According to Author Xochitl Gonzalez
summary: Xochitl Gonzalez recommends six books to read in September 2025.
story: Xochitl Gonzalez stopped by TODAY on Sept. 3 to share the books she's excited about in September, including a thriller-meets-family saga set in the Dominican Republic and two modern classic mysteries.
Gonzalez is the author of novels "Olga Dies Dreaming" and "Anita de Monte Laughs Last," and her next novel, "Last Night in Brooklyn," is a modern retelling of "The Great Gatsby."
Read on for her book picks for September 2025.
Best Thriller
What We Can Know: A Novel

Ian McEwan's "What We Can Know" is set in two time periods: in 2014 and 2119, the latter in which is ravaged by climate change. The book is focused on scholar Tom Metcalfe, who exists in the year 2119 and looks for a poem from 2014 that may be significant not only to him, but to all of humanity.
Best Debut Novel
Dominion: A Novel

Addie E. Citchens' literary debut dives into the inner workings of a small Mississippi town where nothing is as righteous as it seems. “Dominion” uncovers the life of Reverend Sabre Winfrey, shepherd of the Seven Seals Missionary Baptist Church and a fixture of the town. He and his wife, Priscilla, share five young boys — including Emanuel, who goes by Wonderboy, their pride and joy. But when Wonderboy has an unusual encounter with a stranger, it threatens to topple the very structure that keep the Winfreys on top.
Best Binge Read
The Grand Paloma Resort: A Novel

Cleyvis Natera's "The Grand Paloma Resort" explores class, scandal and family. Meet Laura, a manager of the Grand Paloma Resort in the Dominican Republic. Her sister, Elena, is a babysitter at the same hotel, but she hasn’t been the same since their mother’s death, turning to pills and partying as an escape. After a child is found dead under Elena’s care, she finds herself in a seemingly impossible situation. She ends up accepting a risky trade from the child’s father in exchange for private time with two local girls. The deal seems promising — until the girls are reported missing. This tale reveals the cost of luxury and the power of love.
Best Book to Screen
"The Thursday Murder Club"

This first book of this best-selling series introduces the Thursday Murder Club, a group of amateur detectives in a sleepy retirement home. When a local developer turns up dead, the club finds themselves with their first real case — but are they up to the challenge? Then, there's the last book in the series, “The Impossible Fortune,” which comes out later this month. The gang reunites to search for a missing wedding guest named Nick, who has a suspicious business partner.
Watch the movie version of “The Thursday Murder Club” now on Netflix.
The Impossible Fortune: A Thursday Murder Club Mystery
Best Read for Hispanic Heritage Month
Beyond All Reasonable Doubt, Jesus Is Alive!

Melissa Lozada-Oliva is known for her haunting and humorous short stories. This collection, "Beyond All Reasonable Doubt, Jesus Is Alive!," is filled with tales of girls and women, angels and demons alike.

title: 'Dancing With the Stars' Season 34 Cast: See the Celebrities Hitting the Dance Floor
summary: The “Dancing With the Stars” cast for Season 34 is made up of TV personalities, athletes, reality stars and more
story: The “Dancing With the Stars” cast for Season 34 is made up of TV personalities, athletes, reality stars and more.
The full list of celebrities and their professional dance partners vying for a chance to win this season's Len Goodman Mirrorball Trophy was announced on ABC Sept. 3.

A handful of contestants had been announced prior to the big reveal, including Robert Irwin, Alix Earle and "Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” stars Whitney Leavitt and Jen Affleck. It had also been previously revealed that backup dancer Jan Ravnik will be joining the show as a pro dancer.
Julianne Hough and Alfonso Ribeiro return as “DWTS” co-hosts, with Carrie Ann Inaba, Bruno Tonioli and Derek Hough coming back as judges.
Season 33 saw former "Bachelor" star Joey Graziadei and pro Jenna Johnson take first place, while fan-favorite rugby player and Olympian Ilona Maher and Alan Bersten came in second.
Season 34 of “DTWS” premieres on Tuesday, Sept. 16, at 8 p.m. ET on ABC and Disney+, and can be streamed the next day on Hulu.
See the full “Dancing With the Stars” Season 34 cast and dance pros below.
Who is competing in Season 34 of ‘DWTS’?

Robert Irwin was the first celebrity to be announced for Season 34 of “DWTS.” The 21-year-old is a wildlife conservationist, known for his ties to the Australia Zoo and keeping his late father Steve Irwin’s legacy alive.
Irwin is also following in the footsteps of his sister, Bindi Irwin, who competed and won Season 21 of “DWTS” in 2015. Her partner was Derek Hough.
Alix Earle is a social media influencer, with over seven million followers on TikTok. She is known for her “Get Ready With Me” (GRWM) content and vlogging.
Whitney Leavitt is a reality star and influencer known for Hulu’s “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives” and her #MomTok videos.
Jen Affleck gained popularity for being a part of Hulu’s “The Secret Lives of Mormon Wives," and will be joining her co-star Leavitt for this season of "DWTS."
Jan Ravnik, known for being a backup dancer on Taylor Swift's "The Eras Tour," was announced as a pro dancer for Season 34 on Aug. 28.
Olympic gymnast Jordan Chiles is joining the cast of Season 34 along with pro Ezra Sosa.

“I don’t know if my training for gymnastics is really going to help too much with the training of dancing,” Chiles said on ABC Sept 3. “But I definitely can say the work ethic, the part that I feel confident, is definitely there.”
Child star Corey Feldman, known for his roles in 1980s classics like "The Goonies" and "Stand By Me," will be dancing with pro Jenna Johnson.
Lauren Jauregui, one of the members of girl group Fifth Harmony, will be putting her dancing skills to the test with pro Brandon Armstrong.
Pentatonix member Scott Hoying will be paired up with pro Rylee Arnold.
Andy Richter is pivoting from late night comedy to late night dancing on Season 34. He'll be dancing with pro Emma Slater.
"The Parent Trap" star Elaine Hendrix will be paired up with pro Alan Bersten.
NBA All-Star Baron Davis will be swapping out his basketball shoes for dancing shoes as he competes with pro Britt Stewart.
Hilaria Baldwin, the wife of actor Alec Baldwin, will be dancing alongside Gleb Savchenko.
Dylan Efron, the younger brother of Zac Efron, has made his own name in acting and is set to put his dancing skills to the test with pro Daniella Karagach.
Fans of "Boy Meets World" will be excited to see Danielle Fishel as she dances with pro Pasha Pashkov.

title: Taylor Swift Super Bowl Halftime Show Is a ‘Maybe,’ Roger Goodell Says
summary: Will Taylor Swift perform during the halftime show of the next Super Bowl? NFL commissioner Roger Goodell answers the question.
story: Will Taylor Swift perform during the halftime show of the next Super Bowl?
NFL commissioner Roger Goodell wouldn’t say as much, but he certainly didn’t rule out the possibility when asked about it Sept. 3 on TODAY.
“We would always love to have Taylor play. She is a special, special talent, and obviously she would be welcome at any time,” Goodell said.
“Is it in the works?” Savannah Guthrie asked.
“I can’t tell you anything about it,” Goodell replied.
“Is it a maybe?” followed up Savannah.
“It’s a maybe,” he said.
Craig Melvin then asked when people could expect to hear an announcement.
“I’m waiting on my friend Jay-Z,” Goodell joked in response. “It’s in his hands. I’m waiting for the smoke to come out.” (Jay-Z and his company, Roc Nation, produce the Super Bowl halftime shows.)
Swift, of course, has become a presence at Kansas City Chiefs games the last few seasons while dating Travis Kelce. The pair got engaged last month.

Super Bowl 60 will take place Feb. 8 at Levi’s Stadium in Santa Clara, California. The NFL season kicks off Sept. 4 when the defending Super Bowl champions, the Philadelphia Eagles, host the Dallas Cowboys at 8:20 p.m. on NBC.

Goodell also addressed the potential for the Super Bowl to be moved to a different date. While the game has been played in February for several years, there has been chatter around the idea of making the day after it a holiday so people don’t have to go into work after staying up late. That has some fans pushing for the game to be played over Presidents Day weekend.
According to Goodell, the Super Bowl could be played that weekend if the league expands its schedule to include 18 regular season games.

“I think if you went to 18 weeks regular season, that would probably occur,” he said. “It is possible somewhere in the calendar, could happen before that, just because of the calendar it lays out. But I think 18 weeks would get you to that point. I think it’d be a really great move.”
“I do think it makes sense for a lot of reasons. Again, the quality of our game, and also, I think the timing works out great,” he added.

title: Salma Hayek Celebrates 59th Birthday With Annual Bikini Pic
summary: Salma Hayek Pinault toasted to another year around the sun while enjoying a day on the water.
story: Salma Hayek Pinault is celebrating turning 59 the only way she knows how — in a bikini, of course.

On Sept. 2, the “Frida” star marked another year around the sun by continuing her tradition of sharing a bikini snap on her special day. The actor uploaded a photo to Instagram that showed her wearing black sunglasses while holding a red drink in her hand that matched her crimson two-piece. She appeared to be enjoying a day on the water as the sun set behind her.

“59 trips around the sun and still dancing,” she wrote in the caption and included a sun and dancing emoji. She continued, “Cheers to all of you & thank you for the love,” before adding a few celebratory emoji. She also wrote the caption in Spanish.
Celebrity friends and fans wished her a happy birthday in the comments. Director Ava DuVernay cheered, “More life! Enjoy and happy birthday, Lovely!”
“Happy birthday,” two-time Oscar winner Anthony Hopkins said. “We love you.”
A fan complimented the star, writing, “59 never looked better.”

Hayek Pinault has shared countless bikini pictures over the years, and always ushers in her birthday by adding another to the collection. Last year, she posed in a yellow swimsuit while embracing her white hair in honor of her 58th birthday.
“Yellow bikini + White hair = perfect combination,” she captioned the photo before revealing it was taken in Ibiza.
In May, she showed off her figure again when she appeared on the cover of the Sports Illustrated Swimsuit 2025 issue.

Hayek Pinault stopped by TODAY at the time to exclusively reveal the cover photo, in which she posed in a pool in a green bikini by Colombian designer Johanna Ortiz while running her fingers through her hair.

“I used to look at this magazine and wanted to see who was the new, gorgeous model, the new girl of the moment,” she recalled while speaking to Savannah Guthrie and Craig Melvin about the milestone moment. “It never crossed my mind that I could be on that cover. Because (the women) didn’t look like me. My body isn’t necessarily the model type. I never thought that was a possibility — and for it to happen when I’m 58! It’s really shocking.”
Hayek Pinault joined Olympian Jordan Chiles, former gymnast and influencer Olivia Dunne and model and entrepreneur Lauren Chan as the four cover stars.

The “House of Gucci” actor explained on TODAY that she initially experienced imposter syndrome when she was asked to do the cover. But she said her experience on the set of the photo shoot was “magical.”
“My generation, especially Mexican women, we thought we were going to be dismissed at 35,” she shared. “I got so excited and I felt really free. I put Bad Bunny on and started dancing — I loved it.”

title: Jennifer Aniston Reveals Why She Skips the Met Gala
summary: Jennifer Aniston shared why she’s turned down Met Gala invites, saying the high-pressure fashion event leaves her feeling anxious and overwhelmed.
story: Jennifer Aniston might be an A-list star, but there's one guest list she'd prefer to avoid: the Met Gala's.
In a Glamour profile published Sept. 2, the 56-year-old actor explained why the Met Gala red carpet isn’t for her.
“Yes, I have (been invited), but I don’t go,” she told the outlet. “It overwhelms me. It’s the getting ready, the putting on the dress. I’m a ‘jeans and flip-flops and tank top’ kind of girl.”
Aniston added that while she does enjoy dressing up on occasion, the high-profile nature of fashion’s biggest night brings a different kind of pressure.
“For me, it’s a mental game of… ‘Let’s get dressed up, put on a fancy dress, makeup, get your hair all ‘purdy’ and go sit in a big room with your peers,’” she said.
“The Morning Show” actor went on to say that the nerves extend far past the carpet, affecting how she feels during the entire night.
“I even get a little anxious about public speaking, especially over the years of having your words twisted and taken out of context,” she said.
Aniston explained that part of her hesitation comes from how the media has treated her in the past.
“I find myself almost hall-monitoring myself in a weird way. In the past, journalism used to be gnarly and they wanted to just get you and find something that they can then run forever.”
Still, she shared that with time, her perspective has changed.
“You get to a place in life where none of it really matters at the end of the day.”
Beyond red carpets, Aniston said her energy is focused on "The Morning Show" both on-screen and as an executive producer.

“I absolutely love producing and being that involved from the ground up in creating something that’s really high quality,” she shared. “(I’ve learned) that women are beyond capable to make great television and produce a show with elegance and grace and kindness to one another.”

She also praised her “The Morning Show” longtime colleague Reese Witherspoon, calling her “a sister from another mister,” and said their ability to trust one another is what makes the show’s demanding pace work.
The actor returns Sept. 17 in Season 3 of "The Morning Show" on Apple TV+.

title: Brittany Mahomes Shares Pic From Birthday Celebration With Taylor Swift By Her Side
summary: Brittany Mahomes' 30th birthday celebration includes Taylor Swift in Instagram post.
story: Brittany Mahomes rang in her 30th birthday with cocktail towers, silver cowgirl boots and Taylor Swift at her side.

In a Sept. 2 post shared to her Instagram, Mahomes celebrated her big 3-O with pictures highlighting her nights out on the town. In one snap, the mom of three posed solo in a restaurant booth, smiling with a glass in hand. Another image shows a spread of party favors, complete with custom robes embroidered with her name and the ones of her friends.
But it’s the 17th photo in the collection that shows Mahomes sitting next to none other than the “Fortnight” singer.
Mahomes captioned the post simply writing "THIRTY."
The comments section of Mahomes' post was filled with birthday love, including one friend writing, “YES MA’AM!!! 30 and thriving!!!”
Still, it wasn’t just the milestone or the snapshots that had Mahomes’ friends buzzing; Swift’s was the ultimate cherry on top of the post.
“Imagine growing up you and then at 30 your husband is one of the best nfl quarterbacks and your bestie is Taylor Swift,” one user replied. “What a freaking life. Happy Birthday queen!”
“TAYTAY AND BRITTANY,”chimed in a fan.

Mahomes and the newly-engaged singer have developed a close-knit friendship since the singer struck up a romance with Travis Kelce. The Chiefs' tight end is teammates with Mahomes’ husband, quarterback Patrick Mahomes.

Swift first appeared on Brittany Mahomes’ Instagram in November 2023 when she shared a photo of them having champagne with Lyndsay Bell — who is married to former Chiefs tight end Blake Bell — and Paige Buechele, wife of former Chiefs backup quarterback Shane Buechele.

Since then, Brittany Mahomes and Swift have been spotted sharing celebratory BFF handshakes, cheering side by side at the Super Bowl, grabbing dinners in New York and Los Angeles and twinning in red jackets.

In December 2024, Brittany Mahomes and her husband celebrated Swift, not for a birthday but for an “Eras Tour”-themed party thrown in her honor by Kelce. The big celebration marked the end of the singer's record-breaking tour.
Brittany Mahomes sparkled in a sequined minidress, while her husband channeled Swift's dancers in her “I Can Do It With a Broken Heart” performance.

Most recently, Brittany Mahomes celebrated Swift and Kelce's engagement resharing the couple's engagement photos with a caption: “Two of the most genuine people meet & fall in love. Just so happy for these two.”

title: ‘SNL’ Announces New Cast Members Ahead of Season 51
summary: “Saturday Night Live” has announced the group of new faces who will join the sketch-comedy series for its upcoming 51st season, including one fans will recognize.
story: “Saturday Night Live” has announced the group of new faces who will join the sketch-comedy series for its upcoming 51st season, including one fans will recognize.

On Sept. 2, the official “SNL” Instagram account shared the names of the five comedians who will soon be added to the show’s opening credits: Tommy Brennan, Jeremy Culhane, Ben Marshall, Kam Patterson and Veronika Slowikowska.
“Welcome to the cast,” the caption read alongside headshots of each of the newcomers.
In a press release, the long-running NBC series shared more information about the comics and some of their past jobs.

Brennan has performed on “The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon” while Culhane has already built a social media following with viral TikTok videos. Patterson has appeared regularly on the live comedy podcast “Kill Tony,” and Slowikowska already has television experience with roles on shows like “What We Do in the Shadows” and “Poker Face.”

As for Marshall, he has been a part of the “SNL” family for a few years. He has been a member of the writing staff since 2021 and fans will recognize him as a one-third of the comedy trio “Please Don’t Destroy,” appearing in multiple skits over the years beside comics John Higgins and Martin Herlihy.”
Viewers will see Brennan, Culhane, Marshall, Patterson and Slowikowska when Season 51 of “SNL” premieres on Oct. 4 at 11:30 p.m. ET/8:30 p.m. PT, live on both NBC and Peacock.

The news of five additions follows the recent exits of four key cast members. TODAY.com confirmed last week that after eight seasons, Heidi Gardner is departing the show. She has yet to comment on her exit.
Michael Longfellow revealed in an Aug. 28 Instagram post that he is leaving, too.

Beside a slideshow featuring some of his favorite on-camera and behind-the-scenes moments, Longfellow wrote, “Will not be returning for a 4th season at SNL. Wish I was but, so it goes. It was the best three years of my life so far.”

He continued, “Feel nothing but gratitude for the experience and everyone there. Lorne (Michaels), you gave me the greatest job in the world and changed my life. You even put my mom on TV. Thank you doesn't begin to cover it, but thank you.”
Longfellow said he will miss the cast but is looking forward to the future.
Devon Walker, who had been on the show for three years, also announced his departure on Instagram.

He shared a carousel of photos that included a screenshot of a text that read, “I’m out.” In a longer statement, he wrote, in part, “Me and the show did three years together, and sometimes it was really cool. Sometimes it was toxic as hell. But we did what we made the most of what it was, even amidst all of the dysfunction. We made a f—ed up lil family.”
It appears the final comic who won’t return is Emil Wakim, who appeared last season as a featured player.
Wakim said on Instagram that learning about his exit “was a gut punch of a call to get” but added he is “so grateful for my time there.”

“Every time i scanned into the building i would think how insane it is to get to work there,” he continued. “It was the most terrifying, thrilling, and rewarding experience of my life and i will miss it dearly and all the brilliant people that work there that made it feel like a home. thank u to lorne for taking a chance on me and changing my life.”

title: Who Is Leaving ‘SNL’? What Departing Cast Members Have Said
summary: “Saturday Night Live” returns for Season 51 in October. Here's a running list of all the cast members who will not be returning after the landmark 50th season.
story: “Saturday Night Live” returns for its 51st season in just over a month, but without some key players.
After the longstanding NBC sketch comedy show celebrated 50 years on air — commemorated by a three-hour long anniversary special — “SNL” is seeing some changes.
Over the course of the past week, a number of cast members have announced their departure from the show.

Meanwhile, "SNL" shared on Sept. 2 that Please Don't Destroy standup group comedian Ben Marshall, as well as Veronika Slowikowska, Jeremy Culhane, Kam Patterson and Tommy Brennan, are set to join the cast as featured players.
While an official “SNL” cast has yet to be announced for Season 51, creator Lorne Michaels confirmed in an August interview with Puck News that he plans to “shake things up” around the show.
“SNL” Season 51 premieres Saturday, Oct. 4, on NBC.
Here’s a list of who is leaving “SNL” and what they've said about their departure.
Who Is Leaving ‘SNL’?
After eight seasons with the show, Heidi Gardner will not be returning to “SNL” for Season 51, TODAY.com confirmed.
The comedian, who made her “SNL” debut in 2017, has not commented on her departure.
Michael Longfellow, who made his “SNL” debut in 2022, confirmed Aug. 28 that he will not be returning for the show’s 51st season.

In an Instagram post, Longfellow shared a compilation of photos from the live comedy show, writing, “Will not be returning for a 4th season at SNL. Wish I was but, so it goes. It was the best three years of my life so far.”
“I feel nothing but gratitude for the experience and everyone there,” he wrote.
Addressing Michaels, Longfellow told the show creator that he “gave me the greatest job in the world and changed my life,” adding that he “even put my mom on TV.”
“Thank you doesnt begin to cover it, but thank you,” he continued. “I’ll miss it all, but I’ll miss the friends I made and seeing them everyday the most.”
Though he didn’t announce specific plans, Longfellow added that he’s “excited for the future and things to come,” before referring to several inside “SNL” jokes.
Following a three-year run on “SNL,” Walker announced his departure from the show in an Instagram post Aug. 25, writing, “me and baby broke up.”
After a screenshot of a text he appears to have sent reading, “I’m out,” with a partying emoji, he shared a longer message.

“To me, jobs in this industry feel like a bunch of little marriages. Some of ‘em last for a long time if we’re lucky, but most of them are fleeting. Permanent until they’re not. That’s the deal. You know what it is when you sign up," he began.
In his message, Walker, who joined the show in 2022, described his time on the show with, "sometimes it was really cool. Sometimes it was toxic as hell."
"But we did what we made the most of what it was, even amidst all the dysfunction. We made a f----- up lil family," he continued.
As for what’s next, Walker shared he had plans to go to Japan and is “tryna be in a prestige drama” when he returns.
Walker then took to X to address a fan’s post about him and Longfellow leaving “SNL.”
"yall acting like we died lol we just getting different jobs," he wrote.

When asked whether he left the show on his own accord during an interview with Rolling Stone published Aug. 30, Walker once again referred to his experience with “SNL” as a relationship. The comedian said that he and the show “decided together that it was time to go our separate ways.”
“I think I felt ready to leave the show, and I think the show felt ready to leave me,” he continued. “I was just ready to do something else. We both felt like it was time.”
Walker explained that “SNL” posed both a “big time commitment and life commitment.”

“There’s been a lot of life stuff that I feel like I’ve had to miss out on,” he added. “And I felt ready to do a different version of my life. I think that me and the show are both ready to turn the page.”
Wakim, who spent one season as a featured player, announced Aug. 27 that he will not be returning to “SNL.”
The comedian penned a lengthy message on Instagram about leaving the show, writing, “it was a gut punch of a call to get but i’m so grateful for my time there.”
He described signing into 30 Rockefeller Plaza, where "SNL" is filmed, thinking, "how insane it is to get to work there."
"it was the most terrifying, thrilling, and rewarding experience of my life and i will miss it dearly and all the brilliant people that work there that made it feel like a home," Wakim wrote.
He then thanked Michaels "for taking a chance on me and changing my life" when he was cast in Season 50.
“i was so lucky to bring some of myself in there and say things i believed in and i’m excited for whatever chapter comes next. here’s to making more art without compromise,” he concluded.

title: Jason Kelce Gets Candid About Why His Brother and Taylor Swift Work So Well Together
summary: Jason Kelce is sharing why Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift are a perfect match following news of their engagement.
story: Jason Kelce is sharing why Travis Kelce and Taylor Swift are a perfect match following news of their engagement.

The retired NFL player, 37, appeared as a guest on the Sept. 2 episode of the “Bussin’ With The Boys” podcast and gushed about his brother’s romance with the pop star. Toward the end of the three-and-a-half-hour interview, hosts Will Compton and Taylor Lewan, fellow former professional football players, asked Jason Kelce about welcoming Swift into the Kelce family.

“Well, I think first of all, I love my brother. I just want him to have, like, the most fulfilled, best life possible,” Jason Kelce responded. “And such a huge part of that is, like, you know, who you end up marrying, who you end up raising a family with.”
He said he knows his younger brother well and that after getting to know Swift over the past two years, he understands why they fit together.
Jason Kelce continued, “They are unbelievably supportive of each other and both of their outlandishly successful worlds.”

He also said that Swift appreciates qualities in the Kansas City Chiefs star that he admires, as well. The former Philadelphia Eagle referenced Swift’s recent appearance on his “New Heights” podcast, in which she described her beau as a “human exclamation point.”

“The ‘human exclamation point’ was, like, the best way I’ve ever heard Travis described in my life. I think it’s, like, such an accurate statement. The dude just brings joy to every place he ever is and, like, people love him and he makes everything better,” Jason Kelce praised. “To watch them support each other, love each other and get to this stage and now to have this together, I’m just, I mean, I’m very happy for them.”

The podcast co-hosts pointed out that Jason Kelce’s kind words could be used as part of his best man speech at Swift and Travis Kelce’s future wedding. But Jason Kelce revealed he hasn’t been asked to take on that role yet.
“I’m gonna fire up something a lot better,” he replied before adding, “Well, first of all, hopefully I’m the best man. We’ll see. Trav has a lot of friends. I’m just hoping to get the opportunity.”
Compton then asked if Jason Kelce ever worried that his brother wouldn’t find a lifelong partner due to his public persona as a “party animal” and his 2016 reality show, “Catching Kelce.”
The proud big brother answered, “No…I never lost, like, hope that that would happen. I think (it was) just, you know, you’re young, you’re having fun, you’re figuring things out.”
Jason Kelce mentioned that he too struggled with relationships and navigating a love life while being in the NFL before meeting his wife, Kylie Kelce.

“At all times, I know my brother’s intentions and who he is as a person, and the values that my parents raised him with and, you know, how he treats people, how he treats women,” he shared. “He lives his life the right way. He’s a great person. He’s unselfish. Everything he does, I think, would lead to him finding somebody that would want to be with him for all the right reasons and more.”
The Grammy winner and Travis Kelce announced their engagement news on Instagram Aug. 26 with a series of photos from their romantic proposal.
“Your English teacher and your gym teacher are getting married,” they captioned the post, which has over 35 million likes.

title: The 'Bachelor in Paradise' Season Finale Is Tonight. What to Know
summary: The Season 10 finale of "Bachelor in Paradise" airs Tuesday, Sept. 2, on ABC. Here's what to know.
story: With a $500,000 cash prize up for grabs, the season finale of “Bachelor in Paradise” is set to be a dramatic end to the show’s current installment.
On Tuesday, Sept. 2, the Season 10 finale of the reality dating series is set to reveal which couples will further their relationship and which couples will part ways with a two-hour episode.

After a two-year hiatus, “Bachelor in Paradise” returned on July 7. The season featured a unique twist, welcoming contestants from the show’s main series and stars from the franchise’s “Golden” spinoffs to the beach in Costa Rica.
Here’s everything you need to know about when and where to tune in to the season finale.
What Is the Start Time for the 'Bachelor in Paradise' Season 10 Finale?
Fans can tune in to the two-hour-long Season 10 finale of “Bachelor in Paradise” on Sept. 2, starting at 8 p.m. ET.
Where to Watch the 'Bachelor in Paradise' Season 10 Finale
The episode will air on ABC. Fans who miss the live airing can stream the episode the next day on Hulu.
What Do We Know About the Season Finale?
During the “Bachelor in Paradise” finale, the show’s final three couples will be revealed. Final contestants will then be put to the “ultimate relationship test,” according to an ABC press release.

Heading into the show’s final episode, the remaining couples are Kat Izzo and Dale Moss, Kathy Swarts and Keith Gordon, Jess Edwards and Spencer Conley, Bailey Brown and Jeremy Simon, and Alexe Godin and Andrew Spencer.

After two of the five couples left on the beach are eliminated, host Jesse Palmer will unveil their last task, “pushing each couple to the limit in the most revealing and physically demanding test yet,” the release says.
As contestants make big decisions, fans will watch as “the past returns, putting love, trust, and up to $500,000 on the line,” according to ABC.

title: 'Sister Wives' Star Christine Brown Recalls the Moment She Found out About Garrison Brown's Death
summary: In her new memoir, “Sister Wife: A Memoir of Faith, Family, and Finding Freedom," Christine Brown recalled how she find out about the death of Garrison Brown, the son of Kody and Janelle Brown who died by suicide.
story: If you or someone you know is in crisis, call or text 988, or go to 988lifeline.org, to reach the Suicide & Crisis Lifeline. You can also call the network, previously known as the National Suicide Prevention Lifeline, at 800-273-8255, or visit SpeakingOfSuicide.com/resources.
Christine Brown Woolley is calling Garrison Brown's death "the worst thing" that's ever happened to her family in her new memoir, “Sister Wife: A Memoir of Faith, Family, and Finding Freedom."

The book, which was released Sept. 2, explores Brown Woolley's life before, during and after plural marriage and includes a chapter dedicated to Garrison Brown, the son of Kody and Janelle Brown, who died by suicide in March 2024.
In Chapter 40, titled "She Started to Cry," the "Sister Wives" star revealed that Kody and Janelle Brown's son Hunter was the one to break the news to her.

"I'll always remember where I was when I got the call, Hunter on the other end, sobbing," she wrote. "I called (my son) Paedon. Hunter had reached him first. Our sons. His brothers. 'I don't know what to do,' Paedon said. 'We're going to Mykelti's,' I said. We all needed to be together immediately," she writes.
Brown Woolley called her daughter, Mykelti Padron, and said that her other daughter, Aspyn Thompson, had also heard the news.

"So many people to call. So many heartbroken people," she wrote. "We gathered at Mykelti's, held each other while the little kids watched, confused. 'Why is everybody crying?' Mykelti's daughter Avalon asked."
Brown Woolley then recalled having her daughter Gwendlyn Brown "pulled out of class" on the day of Garrison Brown's death and eagerly waiting for her husband David Woolley to return home.
"David was in Park City that day, so it took him an hour and a half to meet us. He was my rock. I've been so independent, but I needed him. My kids needed him," she wrote.
Brown Woolley said that although Woolley hadn't had the chance to get to know Garrison Brown well, he "took it hard" after hearing about the 25-year-old's death.

"Garrison was at our wedding, and he supported our marriage. His loss brought back memories of David's first wife's struggles and death, and the eternal mark it left on his family," she wrote, referring to Woolley's late wife who died by suicide.
"Since Garrison died, David always seems to know ahead of the rest of us what we might need. 'You're never going to be the same,' he's said," she continued.
Since Garrison Brown's death, Janelle Brown has spoken about the role depression and substance abuse played in her son's struggles, a topic that Brown Woolley also addressed in her book.

"We all understood we might lose Garrison, but we thought he might overdo it one night. Or he would crash his car. We don't talk about alcoholism in the young, or about death by suicide. He was so young," Brown Woolley wrote.
The reality star goes on to explain how her husband has supported her since Garrison Brown's death.

"David has encouraged me to go to Al-Anon so I can watch for signs in our other kids, even if there isn't necessarily a way to stop it. You can't change people. But awareness opens a door for conversations, recognition, and safety. And healing," she wrote.
Brown Woolley also noted that Garrison Brown's struggle with alcoholism has made her reevaluate her own drinking habits.

"We know that alcohol can cause depression, and we know we make bad, impulsive decisions. Now I think, Do I really need that? I feel differently now about assuming you can bring a six-pack of beer to someone's house—I think you should ask. I also think this cultural norm that we need alcohol to relax and have a good conversation is just weird," she writes.

title: Vogue's Chloe Malle Is a 'Proud' Nepo Baby. All About Her Famous Parents
summary: Chloe Malle, the new head of editorial content for Vogue U.S., is the daughter of Candice Bergen and the late Louis Malle. Learn about her famous parents.
story: Chloe Malle has some fashionable shoes to fill after being named head of editorial content for Vogue U.S. on Sept. 2, replacing its iconic editor-in-chief, Anna Wintour, who announced in June that she would be relinquishing some of her duties.

Malle, who had been serving as the editor of Vogue.com and co-hosts “The Run-Through with Vogue” podcast, is the only child of Candice Bergen and acclaimed late filmmaker Louis Malle. Her new job also kind of sort of features life imitating art: Bergen once played Vogue’s hypercritical editor-in-chief on “Sex and the City.”
Bergen, in fact, began her career as a model and appeared on the cover of Vogue multiple times.

“There is no question that I have 100 percent benefited from the privilege I grew up in,” Malle told The New York Times after news of her Vogue appointment was announced, calling herself a "proud 'nepo baby'" in the interview.

“It’s delusional to say otherwise. I will say, though, that it has always made me work much harder. It has been a goal for a lot of my life to prove that I’m more than Candice Bergen’s daughter, or someone who grew up in Beverly Hills.”
While Malle looks to continue to make her mark in fashion, her parents did just that in entertainment, showcasing their talents on the big and small screens. Read on to learn more about them.
Candice Bergen

Bergen, 79, is the daughter of famed ventriloquist and comedian Edgar Bergen and is best known for her work as the title character in the CBS sitcom “Murphy Brown.” She played a tough investigative reporter for the fictitious TV newsmagazine “FYI.”

“Murphy Brown” aired for 10 seasons, from 1988 until 1998, and was rebooted for one season in 2018. During its original run, Bergen won five Emmy Awards for outstanding lead actress in a comedy series.
Bergen also notched a pair of Emmy nominations for her work in the drama “Boston Legal.”

She also has a distinguished career in film, earning a best supporting actress Academy Award nomination for “Starting Over.” She also starred in “The Sand Pebbles,” “Carnal Knowledge,” “Gandhi,” “Miss Congeniality,” “Sweet Home Alabama” and “Bride Wars.”
Louis Malle

Malle was a famed French director who earned three Oscar nominations in his lifetime, including one for best director for “Atlantic City.” He also helmed “The Silent World,” a groundbreaking documentary that followed oceanographer Jacques Cousteau and his team of explorers.
In addition, Malle directed such acclaimed titles as “Au Revoir les Enfants,” “Damage,” “Elevator to the Gallows,” “My Dinner with Andre” and “The Lovers.”
Malle died of lymphoma in 1995 at the age of 63.

title: Jenna Bush Hager Says Her September Book Pick Is a 'Once-in-a-Decade' Epic
summary: Jenna Bush Hager reveals her September 2025 book title, which is "Buckeye" by Patrick Ryan.
story: Jenna Bush Hager says “Buckeye” by Patrick Ryan, her September 2025 Read With Jenna pick, is a “once-in-a-decade novel.”
“You read it once and then, even though it’s 500 pages, want to reread again,” she says.
The story is set in the small town of Bonhomie, Ohio, “basically over a lifetime” — from the start of World War II to the end of the Vietnam War.
“We meet two families whose lives intersect in ways that upon Page 1 you could never expect. We watch as America changes and these two families’ lives change,” Jenna says.
"Buckeye" by Patrick Ryan
